awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Commercialization of a real-time, palm-size, low-cost, and wireless SARS-COV-II detector
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a wireless nano-biosensor for detection of live coronavirus particles and potentially other pathogens. Currently, a positive result from an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA)- or polymerase chain reaction (PCR)-based COVID test does not determine if the coronavirus particles are live (infectious) or dead (or neutralized or noninfectious).  The proposed technology is designed to detect interactions of live coronavirus particles with target cells, antibodies, and drugs in real-time. Those with a negative result from the proposed technology have confirmation that they are free of live, infectious coronavirus particles and would not need to quarantine. This technology may provide a tool for effectively combatting the COVID-19 virus and future pandemics/epidemics as well as other infections.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a nano-biosensing methodology for pathogen detection initially focused on SARS COV-II.  The proposed technology integrates a bio-ceramic nanowire/graphene core/shell nanocomposite with a radio frequency identification (RFID) tag on a wireless communication chip surface.  The hardware of the nano-biosensing system is composed of three parts: a radio frequency nano-sensor, a radio frequency reader, and a handheld device or smart phone. The proposed nano-biosensor is made by coating the biosafe nanocomposite on a disposable RFID tag to maximize the sensitivity. Further, nano-biosensors may be integrated to simultaneously detect samples in a multi-well plate, which is versatile and effective in the detection of virus particles, viral antigens, and antibodies, as well as in evaluating virus-neutralizing antibodies and vaccine efficacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Product Outcome for the NSF I-CORPS Grant (Award ID 2230853)

By Ryan Tian, University of Arkansas (UARK)

 

Part-I. New activities that were catalyzed by the NSF I-CORPS Grant:

1)      One large corporate (Tyson Foods, the world #1 in meat-production industry, headquartered in Springdale, AR, that’s next to the UARK campus) has been collaborating with my lab for using our new graphene-based nanobiosensors in their headquarters testing labs to test foodborne bacteria increasingly since May-2024, based on some initial trials in the summer-2022.

2)      Small companies, such as the Avadain LLC (Memphis, TN) and APL LLC (Harrisburg, PA) showed the interest in providing their graphene flakes to support our sensor’s future manufacturing.

3)      UARK Ventures showed their high interest in commercializing this new COVID sensor.

4)      UARK Tech Development Foundation showed their high interest in commercializing this new COVID sensor.

5)      Tyson Venture (>$150 MM) showed the interest to fund our COVID sensor’s commercialization.

6)      Federal agencies showing their high interest in helping commercialize the COVID sensor:

a). The TSA of DHHS showed in the interest in knowing how soon my team can show a demo for WiFi-based wireless detection in real-time and continuingly monitoring of airborne coronavirus and other types of flu viruses.

b). The US Senate HELP Committee has been urging us to show our demo.

 

Part-II. Patent applications, papers, and conference talks that acknowledged the NSF I-CORPS support:

A). Patents:

1)      Templated hydrothermal synthesis of polycrystalline multiwall nanotubes of molybdenum disulfide (MoS2). (Pending)

2)      Templated hydrothermal synthesis of polycrystalline multiwall nanotubes of hexagonal boron nitride (hBN). (Pending)

3)      Airborne pathogen's WiFi-cellphone sensing system. (Pending)

4)      A high-throughput wireless biosensing system from integrating RF-sensors in cell-culture wells. (Pending)

 

B). Papers:

1)      Tian, Y., Zhang, L., Xiao, Y., Collins, T., Akhter, A., Huang, Y., & Tian, Z. R. (2024). Mo-doped titanate nanofibers from hydrothermal syntheses for improving bone scaffold. Characterization and Application of Nanomaterials, 7(1), 3587.

2)      Cole, P., Tian, Y., Thornburgh, S., Malloy, M., Roeder, L., Maulding, M., ... & Tian, Z. R. (2023). Hydrothermal synthesis of valve metal Zr-doped titanate nanofibers for bone tissue engineering. Nano and Medical Materials, 3(2), 249.

3)      Cole, P., Tian, Y., Thornburgh, S., Malloy, M., Roeder, L., Zhang, L., ... & Tian, Z. R. (2024). Hydrothermal synthesis of valve metal Ta-doped titanate nanofibers for potentially engineering bone tissue. Characterization and Application of Nanomaterials, 6(2), 3606.

4)      Ye, X., Tian, Y., Gao, M., Cheng, F., Lan, J., Chen, H., ... & Tian, Z. R. (2024). Efficient Photocatalytic Core–Shell Synthesis of Titanate Nanowire/rGO. Catalysts, 14(4), 218.

 

C). Conference Talks:

1)      Tian, R., Tian, Y., Pechous, R., Malaviarachchi, P., & Zhang, X., (2023, Nov) Multiwall Carbon Nanotubes of Graphene in Bluetooth and Wireless Biosensing of Live Pathogen. AlChE, Orlando, FL.

2)      Tian, Y., Pechous, R., Malaviarachchi, P., Laudadio, J., Hu, H., Tian, Z. R., & Zhang, X., (2023, Jul) Wirelessly Nanosensing Live Viruses and Virus-neutralizing Antibodies in Five Seconds. ASV, Madison, WI.

3)      Tian, Y., Al-Balawi, A., Fan, C., Tian, R., (2022) Wireless, real-time and label-free nanobiosensor for bacteria detection. AMIS, Fayetteville, AR.

4)      Tian, R., Tian, Y., Muhyudin, R., & Gillenwater, P., (2022, Nov) Wirelessly Detect COVID Viruses, Bacteria, and Cells on Graphene Flakes-Improved Nano-Biosensor. AlChE, Phoenix, AZ.

5)      Tian, Y., Acosta, R., Fan, C., & Tian, R. (2022, Aug) Wireless real-time label free nano-biosensor for bacteria detection, ACS, Chicago. IL.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/03/2025
Modified by: Zheng R Tian

Product Outcomefor the NSF I-CORPS Grant (Award ID 2230853)


By Ryan Tian, University of Arkansas (UARK)





Part-I. New activities that were catalyzed by the NSF I-CORPS Grant:


1) One large corporate (Tyson Foods, the world #1 in meat-production industry, headquartered in Springdale, AR, thats next to the UARK campus) has been collaborating with my lab for using our new graphene-based nanobiosensors in their headquarters testing labs to test foodborne bacteria increasingly since May-2024, based on some initial trials in the summer-2022.


2) Small companies, such as the Avadain LLC (Memphis, TN) and APL LLC (Harrisburg, PA) showed the interest in providing their graphene flakes to support our sensors future manufacturing.
